member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics
member.summary: Enumerative Combinatorics and Counting.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.Variations(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Count the number of possible variations without repetition. The order matters and each object can be chosen only once.
member.param: Number of elements in the set.
Number of elements to choose from the set. Each element is chosen at most once.
member.returns: Maximum number of distinct variations.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.VariationsWithRepetition(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Count the number of possible variations with repetition. The order matters and each object can be chosen more than once.
member.param: Number of elements in the set.
Number of elements to choose from the set. Each element is chosen 0, 1 or multiple times.
member.returns: Maximum number of distinct variations with repetition.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.Combinations(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Count the number of possible combinations without repetition. The order does not matter and each object can be chosen only once.
member.param: Number of elements in the set.
Number of elements to choose from the set. Each element is chosen at most once.
member.returns: Maximum number of combinations.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.CombinationsWithRepetition(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Count the number of possible combinations with repetition. The order does not matter and an object can be chosen more than once.
member.param: Number of elements in the set.
Number of elements to choose from the set. Each element is chosen 0, 1 or multiple times.
member.returns: Maximum number of combinations with repetition.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.Permutations(System.Int32)
member.summary: Count the number of possible permutations (without repetition).
member.param: Number of (distinguishable) elements in the set.
member.returns: Maximum number of permutations without repetition.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.GeneratePermutation(System.Int32,System.Random)
member.summary: Generate a random permutation, without repetition, by generating the index numbers 0 to N-1 and shuffle them randomly. Implemented using Fisher-Yates Shuffling.
member.returns: An array of length N that contains (in any order) the integers of the interval [0, N).
member.param: Number of (distinguishable) elements in the set.
The random number generator to use. Optional; the default random source will be used if null.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.SelectPermutationInplace``1(``0[],System.Random)
member.summary: Select a random permutation, without repetition, from a data array by reordering the provided array in-place. Implemented using Fisher-Yates Shuffling. The provided data array will be modified.
member.param: The data array to be reordered. The array will be modified by this routine.
The random number generator to use. Optional; the default random source will be used if null.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.SelectPermutation``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Random)
member.summary: Select a random permutation from a data sequence by returning the provided data in random order. Implemented using Fisher-Yates Shuffling.
member.param: The data elements to be reordered.
The random number generator to use. Optional; the default random source will be used if null.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.GenerateCombination(System.Int32,System.Random)
member.summary: Generate a random combination, without repetition, by randomly selecting some of N elements.
member.param: Number of elements in the set.
The random number generator to use. Optional; the default random source will be used if null.
member.returns: Boolean mask array of length N, for each item true if it is selected.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Combinatorics.GenerateCombination(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Random)
member.summary: Generate a random combination, without repetition, by randomly selecting k of N elements.

Number of elements to choose from the set. Each element is chosen at most once.
The random number generator to use. Optional; the default random source will be used if null.

member.summary: Select a random combination, without repetition, from a data sequence by selecting k elements in original order.

Number of elements (k) to choose from the data set. Each element is chosen at most once.

Number of elements to choose from the set. Elements can be chosen more than once.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Complex32
member.summary: 32-bit single precision complex numbers class.

remarks.para: The class Complex32 provides all elementary operations on complex numbers. All the operators +, -, *, /, ==, != are defined in the canonical way. Additional complex trigonometric functions are also provided. Note that the Complex32 structures has two special constant values and .
For mathematical details about complex numbers, please have a look at the Wikipedia

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.ComplexExtensions.ToComplex(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a complex number based on a string. The string can be in the following formats (without the quotes): 'n', 'ni', 'n +/- ni', 'ni +/- n', 'n,n', 'n,ni,' '(n,n)', or '(n,ni)', where n is a double.
member.returns: A complex number containing the value specified by the given string.
member.param: The string to parse.

member.returns: A complex number containing the value specified by the given string.
member.param: the string to parse.
An that supplies culture-specific formatting information.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.SpeedOfLight
member.summary: Speed of Light in Vacuum: c_0 = 2.99792458e8 [m s^-1] (defined, exact; 2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.MagneticPermeability
member.summary: Magnetic Permeability in Vacuum: mu_0 = 4*Pi * 10^-7 [N A^-2 = kg m A^-2 s^-2] (defined, exact; 2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.ElectricPermittivity
member.summary: Electric Permittivity in Vacuum: epsilon_0 = 1/(mu_0*c_0^2) [F m^-1 = A^2 s^4 kg^-1 m^-3] (defined, exact; 2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.CharacteristicImpedanceVacuum
member.summary: Characteristic Impedance of Vacuum: Z_0 = mu_0*c_0 [Ohm = m^2 kg s^-3 A^-2] (defined, exact; 2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.GravitationalConstant
member.summary: Newtonian Constant of Gravitation: G = 6.67429e-11 [m^3 kg^-1 s^-2] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.PlancksConstant
member.summary: Planck's constant: h = 6.62606896e-34 [J s = m^2 kg s^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.DiracsConstant
member.summary: Reduced Planck's constant: h_bar = h / (2*Pi) [J s = m^2 kg s^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.PlancksMass
member.summary: Planck mass: m_p = (h_bar*c_0/G)^(1/2) [kg] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.PlancksTemperature
member.summary: Planck temperature: T_p = (h_bar*c_0^5/G)^(1/2)/k [K] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.PlancksLength
member.summary: Planck length: l_p = h_bar/(m_p*c_0) [m] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.PlancksTime
member.summary: Planck time: t_p = l_p/c_0 [s] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.ElementaryCharge
member.summary: Elementary Electron Charge: e = 1.602176487e-19 [C = A s] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.MagneticFluxQuantum
member.summary: Magnetic Flux Quantum: theta_0 = h/(2*e) [Wb = m^2 kg s^-2 A^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.ConductanceQuantum
member.summary: Conductance Quantum: G_0 = 2*e^2/h [S = m^-2 kg^-1 s^3 A^2] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.JosephsonConstant
member.summary: Josephson Constant: K_J = 2*e/h [Hz V^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.VonKlitzingConstant
member.summary: Von Klitzing Constant: R_K = h/e^2 [Ohm = m^2 kg s^-3 A^-2] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.BohrMagneton
member.summary: Bohr Magneton: mu_B = e*h_bar/2*m_e [J T^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.NuclearMagneton
member.summary: Nuclear Magneton: mu_N = e*h_bar/2*m_p [J T^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.FineStructureConstant
member.summary: Fine Structure Constant: alpha = e^2/4*Pi*e_0*h_bar*c_0 [1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.RydbergConstant
member.summary: Rydberg Constant: R_infty = alpha^2*m_e*c_0/2*h [m^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.BohrRadius
member.summary: Bor Radius: a_0 = alpha/4*Pi*R_infty [m] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.HartreeEnergy
member.summary: Hartree Energy: E_h = 2*R_infty*h*c_0 [J] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.QuantumOfCirculation
member.summary: Quantum of Circulation: h/2*m_e [m^2 s^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.FermiCouplingConstant
member.summary: Fermi Coupling Constant: G_F/(h_bar*c_0)^3 [GeV^-2] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.WeakMixingAngle
member.summary: Weak Mixin Angle: sin^2(theta_W) [1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Constants.ElectronMass
member.summary: Electron Mass: [kg] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Control
member.summary: Sets parameters for the library.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.UseDefaultProviders
member.summary: Use a specific provider if configured, e.g. using environment variables, or fall back to the best providers.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.UseBestProviders
member.summary: Use the best provider available.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.UseNativeMKL
member.summary: Use the Intel MKL native provider for linear algebra. Throws if it is not available or failed to initialize, in which case the previous provider is still active.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.UseNativeMKL(MathNet.Numerics.Providers.Common.Mkl.MklConsistency,MathNet.Numerics.Providers.Common.Mkl.MklPrecision,MathNet.Numerics.Providers.Common.Mkl.MklAccuracy)
member.summary: Use the Intel MKL native provider for linear algebra, with the specified configuration parameters. Throws if it is not available or failed to initialize, in which case the previous provider is still active.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.TryUseNativeMKL
member.summary: Try to use the Intel MKL native provider for linear algebra.
member.returns: True if the provider was found and initialized successfully. False if it failed and the previous provider is still active.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.UseNativeCUDA
member.summary: Use the Nvidia CUDA native provider for linear algebra. Throws if it is not available or failed to initialize, in which case the previous provider is still active.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.TryUseNativeCUDA
member.summary: Try to use the Nvidia CUDA native provider for linear algebra.
member.returns: True if the provider was found and initialized successfully. False if it failed and the previous provider is still active.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.UseNativeOpenBLAS
member.summary: Use the OpenBLAS native provider for linear algebra. Throws if it is not available or failed to initialize, in which case the previous provider is still active.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.TryUseNativeOpenBLAS
member.summary: Try to use the OpenBLAS native provider for linear algebra.
member.returns: True if the provider was found and initialized successfully. False if it failed and the previous provider is still active.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Control.TryUseNative
member.summary: Try to use any available native provider in an undefined order.
member.returns: True if one of the native providers was found and successfully initialized. False if it failed and the previous provider is still active.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Control.CheckDistributionParameters
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the distribution classes check validate each parameter. For the multivariate distributions this could involve an expensive matrix factorization. The default setting of this property is true.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Control.ThreadSafeRandomNumberGenerators
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use thread safe random number generators (RNG). Thread safe RNG about two and half time slower than non-thread safe RNG.
member.value: true to use thread safe random number generators ; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Control.NativeProviderPath
member.summary: Optional path to try to load native provider binaries from.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Control.MaxDegreeOfParallelism
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating how many parallel worker threads shall be used when parallelization is applicable.
member.remarks: Default to the number of processor cores, must be between 1 and 1024 (inclusive).

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Control.TaskScheduler
member.summary: Gets or sets the TaskScheduler used to schedule the worker tasks.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Control.ParallelizeOrder
member.summary: Gets or sets the order of the matrix when linear algebra provider must calculate multiply in parallel threads.
member.value: The order. Default 64, must be at least 3.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Control.ParallelizeElements
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of elements a vector or matrix must contain before we multiply threads.
member.value: Number of elements. Default 300, must be at least 3.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.FiniteDifferenceCoefficients
member.summary:
Class to calculate finite difference coefficients using Taylor series expansion method.
For n points, coefficients are calculated up to the maximum derivative order possible (n-1). The current function value position specifies the "center" for surrounding coefficients. Selecting the first, middle or last positions represent forward, backwards and central difference methods.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.FiniteDifferenceCoefficients.Points
member.summary: Number of points for finite difference coefficients. Changing this value recalculates the coefficients table.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.FiniteDifferenceCoefficients.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Number of finite difference coefficients.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.FiniteDifferenceCoefficients.GetCoefficients(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the finite difference coefficients for a specified center and order.
member.param: Current function position with respect to coefficients. Must be within point range.
Order of finite difference coefficients.
member.returns: Vector of finite difference coefficients.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.FiniteDifferenceCoefficients.GetCoefficientsForAllOrders(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the finite difference coefficients for all orders at a specified center.
member.param: Current function position with respect to coefficients. Must be within point range.
member.returns: Rectangular array of coefficients, with columns specifying order.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.StepType
member.summary: Type of finite different step size.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.StepType.Absolute
member.summary: The absolute step size value will be used in numerical derivatives, regardless of order or function parameters.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.StepType.RelativeX
member.summary: A base step size value, h, will be scaled according to the function input parameter. A common example is hx = h*(1+abs(x)), however this may vary depending on implementation. This definition only guarantees that the only scaling will be relative to the function input parameter and not the order of the finite difference derivative.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.StepType.Relative
member.summary: A base step size value, eps (typically machine precision), is scaled according to the finite difference coefficient order and function input parameter. The initial scaling according to finite different coefficient order can be thought of as producing a base step size, h, that is equivalent to scaling. This step size is then scaled according to the function input parameter. Although implementation may vary, an example of second order accurate scaling may be (eps)^(1/3)*(1+abs(x)).

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative
member.summary: Class to evaluate the numerical derivative of a function using finite difference approximations. Variable point and center methods can be initialized . This class can also be used to return function handles (delegates) for a fixed derivative order and variable. It is possible to evaluate the derivative and partial derivative of univariate and multivariate functions respectively.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a NumericalDerivative class with the default 3 point center difference method.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialized a NumericalDerivative class.
member.param: Number of points for finite difference derivatives.
Location of the center with respect to other points. Value ranges from zero to points-1.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.StepSize
member.summary: Sets and gets the finite difference step size. This value is for each function evaluation if relative step size types are used. If the base step size used in scaling is desired, see .
member.remarks: Setting then getting the StepSize may return a different value. This is not unusual since a user-defined step size is converted to a base-2 representable number to improve finite difference accuracy.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.BaseStepSize
member.summary: Sets and gets the base finite difference step size. This assigned value to this parameter is only used if is set to RelativeX. However, if the StepType is Relative, it will contain the base step size computed from based on the finite difference order.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.Epsilon
member.summary: Sets and gets the base finite difference step size. This parameter is only used if is set to Relative. By default this is set to machine epsilon, from which is computed.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.Center
member.summary: Sets and gets the location of the center point for the finite difference derivative.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.Evaluations
member.summary: Number of times a function is evaluated for numerical derivatives.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.StepType
member.summary: Type of step size for computing finite differences. If set to absolute, dx = h. If set to relative, dx = (1+abs(x))*h^(2/(order+1)). This provides accurate results when h is approximately equal to the square-root of machine accuracy, epsilon.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.EvaluateDerivative(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates the derivative of equidistant points using the finite difference method.
member.param: Vector of points StepSize apart.
Derivative order.
Finite difference step size.
member.returns: Derivative of points of the specified order.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.EvaluateDerivative(System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Double,System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Double})
member.summary: Evaluates the derivative of a scalar univariate function.
member.remarks: Supplying the optional argument currentValue will reduce the number of function evaluations required to calculate the finite difference derivative.
member.param: Function handle.
Point at which to compute the derivative.
Derivative order.
Current function value at center.
member.returns: Function derivative at x of the specified order.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalDerivative.EvaluateMixedPartialDerivative(System.Func{System.Double[],System.Double},System.Double[],System.Int32[],System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.Double})
member.summary: Evaluates the mixed partial derivative of variable order for multivariate functions.
member.remarks: This function recursively uses to evaluate mixed partial derivative. Therefore, it is more efficient to call for higher order derivatives of a single independent variable.

Vector of indices for the independent variables at descending derivative orders.
Highest order of differentiation.

member.returns: Function mixed partial derivative at x of the specified order.

member.summary: Evaluates the mixed partial derivative of variable order for multivariate function arrays.

member.param: Multivariate function array handle.
Vector at which to evaluate the derivative.
Vector of indices for the independent variables at descending derivative orders.
Highest order of differentiation.
Current function value at center.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalHessian.Evaluate(System.Func{System.Double[],System.Double},System.Double[])
member.summary: Evaluates the Hessian of a multivariate function f at points x.
member.remarks: This method of computing the Hessian is only valid for Lipschitz continuous functions. The function mirrors the Hessian along the diagonal since d2f/dxdy = d2f/dydx for continuously differentiable functions.
member.param: Multivariate function handle.>
Points at which to evaluate Hessian.>
member.returns: Hessian tensor.

member.summary: Resets the function evaluation counter for the Hessian.

member.summary: Number of function evaluations.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a numerical Jacobian object with a three point central difference method.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a numerical Jacobian with a specified differentiation scheme.

Center point for differentiation.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.Evaluate(System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates the Jacobian of scalar univariate function f at point x.
member.param: Scalar univariate function handle.
Point at which to evaluate Jacobian.
member.returns: Jacobian vector.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.Evaluate(System.Func{System.Double[],System.Double},System.Double[])
member.summary: Evaluates the Jacobian of a multivariate function f at vector x.
member.remarks: This function assumes that the length of vector x consistent with the argument count of f.
member.param: Multivariate function handle.
Points at which to evaluate Jacobian.
member.returns: Jacobian vector.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.Evaluate(System.Func{System.Double[],System.Double},System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates the Jacobian of a multivariate function f at vector x given a current function value.
member.remarks: To minimize the number of function evaluations, a user can supply the current value of the function to be used in computing the Jacobian. This value must correspond to the "center" location for the finite differencing. If a scheme is used where the center value is not evaluated, this will provide no added efficiency. This method also assumes that the length of vector x consistent with the argument count of f.
member.param: Multivariate function handle.
Points at which to evaluate Jacobian.
Current function value at finite difference center.
member.returns: Jacobian vector.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.Evaluate(System.Func{System.Double[],System.Double}[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Evaluates the Jacobian of a multivariate function array f at vector x.
member.param: Multivariate function array handle.
Vector at which to evaluate Jacobian.
member.returns: Jacobian matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.Evaluate(System.Func{System.Double[],System.Double}[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Evaluates the Jacobian of a multivariate function array f at vector x given a vector of current function values.
member.remarks: To minimize the number of function evaluations, a user can supply a vector of current values of the functions to be used in computing the Jacobian. These value must correspond to the "center" location for the finite differencing. If a scheme is used where the center value is not evaluated, this will provide no added efficiency. This method also assumes that the length of vector x consistent with the argument count of f.
member.param: Multivariate function array handle.
Vector at which to evaluate Jacobian.
Vector of current function values.
member.returns: Jacobian matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Differentiation.NumericalJacobian.ResetFunctionEvaluations
member.summary: Resets the function evaluation counter for the Jacobian.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Beta
member.summary: Continuous Univariate Beta distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Beta distribution.
member.remarks: There are a few special cases for the parameterization of the Beta distribution. When both shape parameters are positive infinity, the Beta distribution degenerates to a point distribution at 0.5. When one of the shape parameters is positive infinity, the distribution degenerates to a point distribution at the positive infinity. When both shape parameters are 0.0, the Beta distribution degenerates to a Bernoulli distribution with parameter 0.5. When one shape parameter is 0.0, the distribution degenerates to a point distribution at the non-zero shape parameter.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical
member.summary: Discrete Univariate Categorical distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Categorical distribution. This distribution is sometimes called the Discrete distribution.
member.remarks: The distribution is parameterized by a vector of ratios: in other words, the parameter does not have to be normalized and sum to 1. The reason is that some vectors can't be exactly normalized to sum to 1 in floating point representation.
Support: 0..k where k = length(probability mass array)-1

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical.#ctor(System.Double[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Categorical class.
member.param: An array of nonnegative ratios: this array does not need to be normalized as this is often impossible using floating point arithmetic.
member.exception: If any of the probabilities are negative or do not sum to one.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical.#ctor(System.Double[],System.Random)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Categorical class.
member.param: An array of nonnegative ratios: this array does not need to be normalized as this is often impossible using floating point arithmetic.
The random number generator which is used to draw random samples.
member.exception: If any of the probabilities are negative or do not sum to one.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical.#ctor(MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Histogram)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Categorical class from a . The distribution will not be automatically updated when the histogram changes. The categorical distribution will have one value for each bucket and a probability for that value proportional to the bucket count.
member.param: The histogram from which to create the categorical variable.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Chi
member.summary: Continuous Univariate Chi distribution. This distribution is a continuous probability distribution. The distribution usually arises when a k-dimensional vector's orthogonal components are independent and each follow a standard normal distribution. The length of the vector will then have a chi distribution. Wikipedia - Chi distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.ConwayMaxwellPoisson
member.summary:
Discrete Univariate Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution.
The Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution is a generalization of the Poisson, Geometric and Bernoulli distributions. It is parameterized by two real numbers "lambda" and "nu". For
nu = 0 the distribution reverts to a Geometric distribution
nu = 1 the distribution reverts to the Poisson distribution
nu -> infinity the distribution converges to a Bernoulli distribution
This implementation will cache the value of the normalization constant. Wikipedia - ConwayMaxwellPoisson distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Gamma
member.summary: Continuous Univariate Gamma distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Gamma distribution.
member.remarks:
The Gamma distribution is parametrized by a shape and inverse scale parameter. When we want to specify a Gamma distribution which is a point distribution we set the shape parameter to be the location of the point distribution and the inverse scale as positive infinity. The distribution with shape and inverse scale both zero is undefined.
Random number generation for the Gamma distribution is based on the algorithm in: "A Simple Method for Generating Gamma Variables" - Marsaglia & Tsang ACM Transactions on Mathematical Software, Vol. 26, No. 3, September 2000, Pages 363372.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Hypergeometric
member.summary: Discrete Univariate Hypergeometric distribution. This distribution is a discrete probability distribution that describes the number of successes in a sequence of n draws from a finite population without replacement, just as the binomial distribution describes the number of successes for draws with replacement Wikipedia - Hypergeometric distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.MatrixNormal
member.summary: Multivariate Matrix-valued Normal distributions. The distribution is parameterized by a mean matrix (M), a covariance matrix for the rows (V) and a covariance matrix for the columns (K). If the dimension of M is d-by-m then V is d-by-d and K is m-by-m. Wikipedia - MatrixNormal distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Multinomial
member.summary: Multivariate Multinomial distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Multinomial distribution.
member.remarks: The distribution is parameterized by a vector of ratios: in other words, the parameter does not have to be normalized and sum to 1. The reason is that some vectors can't be exactly normalized to sum to 1 in floating point representation.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.NegativeBinomial
member.summary: Discrete Univariate Negative Binomial distribution. The negative binomial is a distribution over the natural numbers with two parameters r, p. For the special case that r is an integer one can interpret the distribution as the number of failures before the r'th success when the probability of success is p. Wikipedia - NegativeBinomial distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.NormalGamma
member.summary:
Multivariate Normal-Gamma Distribution.
The distribution is the conjugate prior distribution for the distribution. It specifies a prior over the mean and precision of the distribution.
It is parameterized by four numbers: the mean location, the mean scale, the precision shape and the precision inverse scale.
The distribution NG(mu, tau | mloc,mscale,psscale,pinvscale) = Normal(mu | mloc, 1/(mscale*tau)) * Gamma(tau | psscale,pinvscale).
The following degenerate cases are special: when the precision is known, the precision shape will encode the value of the precision while the precision inverse scale is positive infinity. When the mean is known, the mean location will encode the value of the mean while the scale will be positive infinity. A completely degenerate NormalGamma distribution with known mean and precision is possible as well. Wikipedia - Normal-Gamma distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Pareto
member.summary: Continuous Univariate Pareto distribution. member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Rayleigh
member.summary: Continuous Univariate Rayleigh distribution. The Rayleigh distribution (pronounced /reli/) is a continuous probability distribution. As an example of how it arises, the wind speed will have a Rayleigh distribution if the components of the two-dimensional wind velocity vector are uncorrelated and normally distributed with equal variance. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Rayleigh distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Stable
member.summary: Continuous Univariate Stable distribution. A random variable is said to be stable (or to have a stable distribution) if it has the property that a linear combination of two independent copies of the variable has the same distribution, up to location and scale parameters. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Stable distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.StudentT
member.summary:
Continuous Univariate Student's T-distribution. Implements the univariate Student t-distribution. For details about this distribution, see
Wikipedia - Student's t-distribution.

remarks.para: We use a slightly generalized version (compared to Wikipedia) of the Student t-distribution. Namely, one which also parameterizes the location and scale. See the book "Bayesian Data Analysis" by Gelman et al. for more details.
The density of the Student t-distribution p(x|mu,scale,dof) = Gamma((dof+1)/2) (1 + (x - mu)^2 / (scale * scale * dof))^(-(dof+1)/2) / (Gamma(dof/2)*Sqrt(dof*pi*scale)).
The distribution will use the by default. Users can get/set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Triangular
member.summary: Triangular distribution. For details, see Wikipedia - Triangular distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution will use the by default. Users can get/set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check whether all the incoming parameters are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Wishart
member.summary: Multivariate Wishart distribution. This distribution is parameterized by the degrees of freedom nu and the scale matrix S. member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Zipf
member.summary: Discrete Univariate Zipf distribution. Zipf's law, an empirical law formulated using mathematical statistics, refers to the fact that many types of data studied in the physical and social sciences can be approximated with a Zipfian distribution, one of a family of related discrete power law probability distributions. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Zipf distribution.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteReturnMeasures.CompoundReturn(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Compound Monthly Return or Geometric Return or Annualized Return

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteReturnMeasures.GainMean(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Average Gain or Gain Mean This is a simple average (arithmetic mean) of the periods with a gain. It is calculated by summing the returns for gain periods (return 0) and then dividing the total by the number of gain periods.
member.remarks: http://www.offshore-library.com/kb/statistics.php

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteReturnMeasures.LossMean(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Average Loss or LossMean This is a simple average (arithmetic mean) of the periods with a loss. It is calculated by summing the returns for loss periods (return < 0) and then dividing the total by the number of loss periods.
member.remarks: http://www.offshore-library.com/kb/statistics.php

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteRiskMeasures.GainStandardDeviation(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Calculation is similar to Standard Deviation , except it calculates an average (mean) return only for periods with a gain and measures the variation of only the gain periods around the gain mean. Measures the volatility of upside performance. Copyright 1996, 1999 Gary L.Gastineau. First Edition. 1992 Swiss Bank Corporation.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteRiskMeasures.LossStandardDeviation(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Similar to standard deviation, except this statistic calculates an average (mean) return for only the periods with a loss and then measures the variation of only the losing periods around this loss mean. This statistic measures the volatility of downside performance.
member.remarks: http://www.offshore-library.com/kb/statistics.php

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteRiskMeasures.DownsideDeviation(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: This measure is similar to the loss standard deviation except the downside deviation considers only returns that fall below a defined minimum acceptable return (MAR) rather than the arithmetic mean. For example, if the MAR is 7%, the downside deviation would measure the variation of each period that falls below 7%. (The loss standard deviation, on the other hand, would take only losing periods, calculate an average return for the losing periods, and then measure the variation between each losing return and the losing return average).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteRiskMeasures.SemiDeviation(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: A measure of volatility in returns below the mean. It's similar to standard deviation, but it only looks at periods where the investment return was less than average return.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Financial.AbsoluteRiskMeasures.GainLossRatio(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Measures a funds average gain in a gain period divided by the funds average loss in a losing period. Periods can be monthly or quarterly depending on the data frequency.

member.summary: Find both complex roots of the quadratic equation c + b*x + a*x^2 = 0. Note the special coefficient order ascending by exponent (consistent with polynomials).

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Fit
member.summary: Least-Squares Curve Fitting Routines

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.Line(System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a line y : x -> a+b*x, returning its best fitting parameters as [a, b] array, where a is the intercept and b the slope.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.LineFunc(System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a line y : x -> a+b*x, returning a function y' for the best fitting line.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.LineThroughOrigin(System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a line through origin y : x -> b*x, returning its best fitting parameter b, where the intercept is zero and b the slope.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.LineThroughOriginFunc(System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a line through origin y : x -> b*x, returning a function y' for the best fitting line.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.Exponential(System.Double[],System.Double[],MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to an exponential y : x -> a*exp(r*x), returning its best fitting parameters as (a, r) tuple.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.ExponentialFunc(System.Double[],System.Double[],MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to an exponential y : x -> a*exp(r*x), returning a function y' for the best fitting line.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.Logarithm(System.Double[],System.Double[],MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a logarithm y : x -> a + b*ln(x), returning its best fitting parameters as (a, b) tuple.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.LogarithmFunc(System.Double[],System.Double[],MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a logarithm y : x -> a + b*ln(x), returning a function y' for the best fitting line.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.Power(System.Double[],System.Double[],MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a power y : x -> a*x^b, returning its best fitting parameters as (a, b) tuple.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.PowerFunc(System.Double[],System.Double[],MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a power y : x -> a*x^b, returning a function y' for the best fitting line.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.Polynomial(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a k-order polynomial y : x -> p0 + p1*x + p2*x^2 + ... + pk*x^k, returning its best fitting parameters as [p0, p1, p2, ..., pk] array, compatible with Evaluate.Polynomial. A polynomial with order/degree k has (k+1) coefficients and thus requires at least (k+1) samples.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.PolynomialFunc(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,MathNet.Numerics.LinearRegression.DirectRegressionMethod)
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to a k-order polynomial y : x -> p0 + p1*x + p2*x^2 + ... + pk*x^k, returning a function y' for the best fitting polynomial. A polynomial with order/degree k has (k+1) coefficients and thus requires at least (k+1) samples.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.PolynomialWeighted(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Weighted Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) and weights w to a k-order polynomial y : x -> p0 + p1*x + p2*x^2 + ... + pk*x^k, returning its best fitting parameters as [p0, p1, p2, ..., pk] array, compatible with Evaluate.Polynomial. A polynomial with order/degree k has (k+1) coefficients and thus requires at least (k+1) samples.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fit.LinearCombination(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Func{System.Double,System.Double}[])
member.summary: Least-Squares fitting the points (x,y) to an arbitrary linear combination y : x -> p0*f0(x) + p1*f1(x) + ... + pk*fk(x), returning its best fitting parameters as [p0, p1, p2, ..., pk] array.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Generate.Periodic(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a periodic wave.
member.param: The number of samples to generate.
Samples per time unit (Hz). Must be larger than twice the frequency to satisfy the Nyquist criterion.
Frequency in periods per time unit (Hz).
The length of the period when sampled at one sample per time unit. This is the interval of the periodic domain, a typical value is 1.0, or 2*Pi for angular functions.
Optional phase offset.
Optional delay, relative to the phase.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.Fourier.ForwardReal(System.Single[],System.Int32,MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.FourierOptions)
member.summary: Packed Real-Complex forward Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to arbitrary-length sample vectors. Since for real-valued time samples the complex spectrum is conjugate-even (symmetry), the spectrum can be fully reconstructed form the positive frequencies only (first half). The data array needs to be N+2 (if N is even) or N+1 (if N is odd) long in order to support such a packed spectrum.
member.param: Data array of length N+2 (if N is even) or N+1 (if N is odd).
The number of samples.
Fourier Transform Convention Options.

The data array needs to be N+2 (if N is even) or N+1 (if N is odd) long in order to support such a packed spectrum.
member.param: Data array of length N+2 (if N is even) or N+1 (if N is odd).
The number of samples.
Fourier Transform Convention Options.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.Fourier.FrequencyScale(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Generate the frequencies corresponding to each index in frequency space. The frequency space has a resolution of sampleRate/N. Index 0 corresponds to the DC part, the following indices correspond to the positive frequencies up to the Nyquist frequency (sampleRate/2), followed by the negative frequencies wrapped around.
member.param: Number of samples.
The sampling rate of the time-space data.

member.summary: Fourier Transform Convention

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.FourierOptions.InverseExponent
member.summary: Inverse integrand exponent (forward: positive sign; inverse: negative sign).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.FourierOptions.AsymmetricScaling
member.summary: Only scale by 1/N in the inverse direction; No scaling in forward direction.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.FourierOptions.NoScaling
member.summary: Don't scale at all (neither on forward nor on inverse transformation).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.FourierOptions.Default
member.summary: Universal; Symmetric scaling and common exponent (used in Maple).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.FourierOptions.Matlab
member.summary: Only scale by 1/N in the inverse direction; No scaling in forward direction (used in Matlab). [= AsymmetricScaling]

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.IntegralTransforms.FourierOptions.NumericalRecipes
member.summary: Inverse integrand exponent; No scaling at all (used in all Numerical Recipes based implementations). [= InverseExponent | NoScaling]

Where the interval stops, inclusive and finite.
The expected relative accuracy of the approximation.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Integrate.OnClosedInterval(System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Approximation of the definite integral of an analytic smooth function on a closed interval.
member.param: The analytic smooth function to integrate.
Where the interval starts, inclusive and finite.
Where the interval stops, inclusive and finite.
member.returns: Approximation of the finite integral in the given interval.

members.member:
Approximates a 2-dimensional definite integral using an Nth order Gauss-Legendre rule over the rectangle [a,b] x [c,d].
The 2-dimensional analytic smooth function to integrate. Where the interval starts for the first (inside) integral, exclusive and finite. Where the interval ends for the first (inside) integral, exclusive and finite. Where the interval starts for the second (outside) integral, exclusive and finite. /// Where the interval ends for the second (outside) integral, exclusive and finite. Defines an Nth order Gauss-Legendre rule. The order also defines the number of abscissas and weights for the rule. Precomputed Gauss-Legendre abscissas/weights for orders 2-20, 32, 64, 96, 100, 128, 256, 512, 1024 are used, otherwise they're calculated on the fly. Approximation of the finite integral in the given interval.

Approximates a 2-dimensional definite integral using an Nth order Gauss-Legendre rule over the rectangle [a,b] x [c,d].

Approximation of the finite integral in the given interval.

member.summary: Computes the Gauss-Legendre abscissas/weights. See Pavel Holoborodko for a description of the algorithm.
member.param: Defines an Nth order Gauss-Legendre rule. The order also defines the number of abscissas and weights for the rule.
Required precision to compute the abscissas/weights. 1e-10 is usually fine.
member.returns: Object containing the non-negative abscissas/weights, order, and intervalBegin/intervalEnd. The non-negative abscissas/weights are generated over the interval [-1,1] for the given order.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.NevillePolynomialInterpolation
member.summary: Lagrange Polynomial Interpolation using Neville's Algorithm.

remarks.para: This algorithm supports differentiation, but doesn't support integration.
When working with equidistant or Chebyshev sample points it is recommended to use the barycentric algorithms specialized for these cases instead of this arbitrary Neville algorithm.

member.summary: Number of rows.
member.remarks: Using this instead of the RowCount property to speed up calculating a matrix index in the data array.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix._columnCount
member.summary: Number of columns.
member.remarks: Using this instead of the ColumnCount property to speed up calculating a matrix index in the data array.

member.summary: Gets the matrix's data.
member.value: The matrix's data.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.#ctor(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Storage.DenseColumnMajorMatrixStorage{System.Double})
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix straight from an initialized matrix storage instance. The storage is used directly without copying. Intended for advanced scenarios where you're working directly with storage for performance or interop reasons.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a new square dense matrix with the given number of rows and columns. All cells of the matrix will be initialized to zero. Zero-length matrices are not supported.
member.exception: If the order is less than one.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix with the given number of rows and columns. All cells of the matrix will be initialized to zero. Zero-length matrices are not supported.
member.exception: If the row or column count is less than one.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix with the given number of rows and columns directly binding to a raw array. The array is assumed to be in column-major order (column by column) and is used directly without copying. Very efficient, but changes to the array and the matrix will affect each other.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.OfMatrix(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Matrix{System.Double})
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix as a copy of the given other matrix. This new matrix will be independent from the other matrix. A new memory block will be allocated for storing the matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.OfArray(System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix as a copy of the given two-dimensional array. This new matrix will be independent from the provided array. A new memory block will be allocated for storing the matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.OfIndexed(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Tuple{System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double}})
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix as a copy of the given indexed enumerable. Keys must be provided at most once, zero is assumed if a key is omitted. This new matrix will be independent from the enumerable. A new memory block will be allocated for storing the matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.OfColumnMajor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double})
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix as a copy of the given enumerable. The enumerable is assumed to be in column-major order (column by column). This new matrix will be independent from the enumerable. A new memory block will be allocated for storing the matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix.OfColumns(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double}})
member.summary: Create a new dense matrix as a copy of the given enumerable of enumerable columns. Each enumerable in the master enumerable specifies a column. This new matrix will be independent from the enumerables. A new memory block will be allocated for storing the matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DiagonalMatrix
member.summary: A matrix type for diagonal matrices.
member.remarks: Diagonal matrices can be non-square matrices but the diagonal always starts at element 0,0. A diagonal matrix will throw an exception if non diagonal entries are set. The exception to this is when the off diagonal elements are 0.0 or NaN; these settings will cause no change to the diagonal matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.Cholesky

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.Cholesky.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the Cholesky matrix was computed.

member.summary: Gets the log determinant of the matrix for which the Cholesky matrix was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.DenseEvd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VT=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.DenseEvd.Create(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.DenseMatrix,MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Symmetricity)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. This object will compute the the eigenvalue decomposition when the constructor is called and cache it's decomposition.
member.param: The matrix to factor.
If it is known whether the matrix is symmetric or not the routine can skip checking it itself.
member.exception: If EVD algorithm failed to converge with matrix .

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.DenseGramSchmidt

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition Modified Gram-Schmidt Orthogonalization.
Any real square matrix A may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal mxn matrix and R is an nxn upper triangular matrix.

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by modified Gram-Schmidt Orthogonalization.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.DenseLU

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of an LU factorization.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.Evd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VT=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition(). Matrix V is encoded in the property EigenVectors in the way that: - column corresponding to real eigenvalue represents real eigenvector, - columns corresponding to the pair of complex conjugate eigenvalues lambda[i] and lambda[i+1] encode real and imaginary parts of eigenvectors.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.Evd.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the absolute value of determinant of the square matrix for which the EVD was computed.

member.summary: Gets the effective numerical matrix rank.
member.value: The number of non-negligible singular values.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.Evd.IsFullRank
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix is full rank or not.
member.value: true if the matrix is full rank; otherwise false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.LU

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of an LU factorization.
For a matrix A, the LU factorization is a pair of lower triangular matrix L and upper triangular matrix U so that A = L*U.
In the Math.Net implementation we also store a set of pivot elements for increased numerical stability. The pivot elements encode a permutation matrix P such that P*A = L*U.

member.remarks: The computation of the LU factorization is done at construction time.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.LU.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the LU factorization was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.QR

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition.

Any real square matrix A (m x n) may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal matrix (its columns are orthogonal unit vectors meaning QTQ = I) and R is an upper triangular matrix (also called right triangular matrix).

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by Householder transformation. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x m matrix and the R matrix is an m x n matrix. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x n matrix and the R matrix is an n x n matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Factorization.UserCholesky

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization for user matrices.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.BiCgStab
member.summary: A Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Bi-Conjugate Gradient Stabilized (BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard Conjugate Gradient (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the BiCGStab can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The Bi-CGSTAB algorithm was taken from:
Templates for the solution of linear systems: Building blocks for iterative methods
Richard Barrett, Michael Berry, Tony F. Chan, James Demmel, June M. Donato, Jack Dongarra, Victor Eijkhout, Roldan Pozo, Charles Romine and Henk van der Vorst
Url: http://www.netlib.org/templates/Templates.html
Algorithm is described in Chapter 2, section 2.3.8, page 27
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.BiCgStab.CalculateTrueResidual(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Matrix{System.Double},MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector{System.Double},MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector{System.Double},MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector{System.Double})

The preconditioner to use for approximations.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.CompositeSolver
member.summary: A composite matrix solver. The actual solver is made by a sequence of matrix solvers.

remarks.para:
Solver based on:
Faster PDE-based simulations using robust composite linear solvers
S. Bhowmicka, P. Raghavan a,*, L. McInnes b, B. Norris
Future Generation Computer Systems, Vol 20, 2004, pp 373387
Note that if an iterator is passed to this solver it will be used for all the sub-solvers.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.GpBiCg
member.summary: A Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient (GPBiCG) solver is an alternative version of the Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the GPBiCG solver can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The GPBiCG algorithm was taken from:
GPBiCG(m,l): A hybrid of BiCGSTAB and GPBiCG methods with efficiency and robustness
S. Fujino
Applied Numerical Mathematics, Volume 41, 2002, pp 107 - 117
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner
member.summary: This class performs an Incomplete LU factorization with drop tolerance and partial pivoting. The drop tolerance indicates which additional entries will be dropped from the factorized LU matrices.
member.remarks:
The ILUTP-Mem algorithm was taken from:
ILUTP_Mem: a Space-Efficient Incomplete LU Preconditioner
Tzu-Yi Chen, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science,
Pomona College, Claremont CA 91711, USA
Published in:
Lecture Notes in Computer Science
Volume 3046 / 2004
pp. 20 - 28
Algorithm is described in Section 2, page 22

member.summary: The default drop tolerance.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the default settings.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified settings.
member.param: The amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. Values should be positive.

The absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. A drop tolerance of 0.0 means that no values will be dropped. Values should always be positive.
The pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. A value of 0.0 means that no pivoting will take place.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.FillLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. The standard value is 200.

remarks.para: Values should always be positive and can be higher than 1.0. A value lower than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner matrix will have fewer non-zero entries as the original matrix. A value higher than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner can have more non-zero values than the original matrix.
Note that any changes to the FillLevel after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.DropTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. The standard value is 0.0001.

remarks.para: The values should always be positive and can be larger than 1.0. A low value will keep more small numbers in the preconditioner matrix. A high value will remove more small numbers from the preconditioner matrix.
Note that any changes to the DropTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.PivotTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. The standard value is 0.0 which means pivoting will never take place.

remarks.para: The pivot tolerance is used to calculate if pivoting is necessary. Pivoting will take place if any of the values in a row is bigger than the diagonal value of that row divided by the pivot tolerance, i.e. pivoting will take place if row(i,j) > row(i,i) / PivotTolerance for any j that is not equal to i.
Note that any changes to the PivotTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.UpperTriangle
member.summary: Returns the upper triagonal matrix that was created during the LU decomposition.
member.remarks: This method is used for debugging purposes only and should normally not be used.
member.returns: A new matrix containing the upper triagonal elements.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.LowerTriangle
member.summary: Returns the lower triagonal matrix that was created during the LU decomposition.
member.remarks: This method is used for debugging purposes only and should normally not be used.
member.returns: A new matrix containing the lower triagonal elements.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.Pivots
member.summary: Returns the pivot array. This array is not needed for normal use because the preconditioner will return the solution vector values in the proper order.
member.remarks: This method is used for debugging purposes only and should normally not be used.
member.returns: The pivot array.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.Initialize(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Matrix{System.Double})

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Double.Solvers.MlkBiCgStab
member.summary: A Multiple-Lanczos Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para: The Multiple-Lanczos Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (ML(k)-BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard BiCgStab solver.

The algorithm was taken from:
ML(k)BiCGSTAB: A BiCGSTAB variant based on multiple Lanczos starting vectors
Man-Chung Yeung and Tony F. Chan
SIAM Journal of Scientific Computing
Volume 21, Number 4, pp. 1263 - 1290
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.summary: The collection of starting vectors which are used as the basis for the Krylov sub-space.

member.summary: The number of starting vectors used by the algorithm

member.summary: Resets the number of starting vectors to the default value.

member.summary: Gets or sets a series of orthonormal vectors which will be used as basis for the Krylov sub-space.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.DiagonalMatrix
member.summary: A matrix type for diagonal matrices.
member.remarks: Diagonal matrices can be non-square matrices but the diagonal always starts at element 0,0. A diagonal matrix will throw an exception if non diagonal entries are set. The exception to this is when the off diagonal elements are 0.0 or NaN; these settings will cause no change to the diagonal matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.Cholesky

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.Cholesky.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the Cholesky matrix was computed.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.Cholesky.DeterminantLn
member.summary: Gets the log determinant of the matrix for which the Cholesky matrix was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.DenseCholesky

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization for dense matrices.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. This object will compute the Cholesky factorization when the constructor is called and cache it's factorization.
member.param: The matrix to factor.
member.exception: If is not a square matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.DenseEvd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VT=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.DenseEvd.Create(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.DenseMatrix,MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Symmetricity)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. This object will compute the the eigenvalue decomposition when the constructor is called and cache it's decomposition.
member.param: The matrix to factor.
If it is known whether the matrix is symmetric or not the routine can skip checking it itself.
member.exception: If EVD algorithm failed to converge with matrix .

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.LU

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of an LU factorization.
For a matrix A, the LU factorization is a pair of lower triangular matrix L and upper triangular matrix U so that A = L*U.
In the Math.Net implementation we also store a set of pivot elements for increased numerical stability. The pivot elements encode a permutation matrix P such that P*A = L*U.

member.remarks: The computation of the LU factorization is done at construction time.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.LU.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the LU factorization was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.QR

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition.

Any real square matrix A (m x n) may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal matrix (its columns are orthogonal unit vectors meaning QTQ = I) and R is an upper triangular matrix (also called right triangular matrix).

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by Householder transformation. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x m matrix and the R matrix is an m x n matrix. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x n matrix and the R matrix is an n x n matrix.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.QR.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the absolute determinant value of the matrix for which the QR matrix was computed.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.QR.IsFullRank
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix is full rank or not.
member.value: true if the matrix is full rank; otherwise false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Factorization.UserCholesky

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization for user matrices.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Solvers.BiCgStab
member.summary: A Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Bi-Conjugate Gradient Stabilized (BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard Conjugate Gradient (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the BiCGStab can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The Bi-CGSTAB algorithm was taken from:
Templates for the solution of linear systems: Building blocks for iterative methods
Richard Barrett, Michael Berry, Tony F. Chan, James Demmel, June M. Donato, Jack Dongarra, Victor Eijkhout, Roldan Pozo, Charles Romine and Henk van der Vorst
Url: http://www.netlib.org/templates/Templates.html
Algorithm is described in Chapter 2, section 2.3.8, page 27
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Solvers.BiCgStab.CalculateTrueResidual(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Matrix{System.Single},MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector{System.Single},MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector{System.Single},MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector{System.Single})
member.summary: Calculates the true residual of the matrix equation Ax = b according to: residual = b - Ax
member.param: Instance of the A.
Residual values in .
Instance of the x.
Instance of the b.

member.summary: Solves the matrix equation Ax = b, where A is the coefficient matrix, b is the solution vector and x is the unknown vector.
member.param: The coefficient , A.
The solution , b.
The result , x.
The iterator to use to control when to stop iterating.
The preconditioner to use for approximations.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Solvers.CompositeSolver
member.summary: A composite matrix solver. The actual solver is made by a sequence of matrix solvers.

remarks.para:
Solver based on:
Faster PDE-based simulations using robust composite linear solvers
S. Bhowmicka, P. Raghavan a,*, L. McInnes b, B. Norris
Future Generation Computer Systems, Vol 20, 2004, pp 373387
Note that if an iterator is passed to this solver it will be used for all the sub-solvers.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Solvers.GpBiCg
member.summary: A Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient (GPBiCG) solver is an alternative version of the Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the GPBiCG solver can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The GPBiCG algorithm was taken from:
GPBiCG(m,l): A hybrid of BiCGSTAB and GPBiCG methods with efficiency and robustness
S. Fujino
Applied Numerical Mathematics, Volume 41, 2002, pp 107 - 117
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Single.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner
member.summary: This class performs an Incomplete LU factorization with drop tolerance and partial pivoting. The drop tolerance indicates which additional entries will be dropped from the factorized LU matrices.
member.remarks:
The ILUTP-Mem algorithm was taken from:
ILUTP_Mem: a Space-Efficient Incomplete LU Preconditioner
Tzu-Yi Chen, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science,
Pomona College, Claremont CA 91711, USA
Published in:
Lecture Notes in Computer Science
Volume 3046 / 2004
pp. 20 - 28
Algorithm is described in Section 2, page 22
